Yes, farmers often use a combination of different fertilizers to achieve the appropriate balance of nutrients in the soil. This is known as a balanced fertilization program, and it involves analyzing the soil to determine which nutrients are deficient and then applying the appropriate fertilizers accordingly.

There are several methods that farmers use to determine which fertilizer to use for each crop. One common method is soil testing, where samples of the soil are analyzed in a laboratory to determine their nutrient content. Based on the soil test results, farmers can select the appropriate fertilizers to balance the nutrients.

Another method is crop nutrient recommendations, where researchers and extension agents develop guidelines for nutrient application rates based on the crop type, soil type, and other factors. Farmers can use these guidelines as a starting point and then make adjustments based on their own soil test results and experience.

In general, farmers try to achieve a balance of macronutrients and micronutrients to promote healthy crop growth and yield. The type and amount of fertilizer used can also vary depending on the crop stage and environmental conditions, so farmers must monitor the soil and make adjustments as necessary throughout the growing season.
